            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\\( \\frac{3x}{x^2+4} \\)",
                "Misconception": "Simplifies a fraction by adding or subtracting the same amount from the numerator  and denominator"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\\( \\frac{3}{x+1} \\)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Does not simplify",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to simplify algebraic fractions"

Misconception 1843/1869:
Here's another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Interpret the gradient on a linear section on a real life graph",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "A car is moving along a straight road.
The graph on the right shows the car's speed in kilometres per hour \( (v) \) over time in hours
\( (t) \).

The gradient of the positively sloping section of the graph is \( 2.5 \).

Which of the following does that \( 2.5 \) best represent? ![A sketch of a graph with v on the y axis and t on the x axis. A straight line slopes upwards from the origin 1/2 of the way up the graph, 1/4 across the graph. It then becomes horizontal for the next 1/4 of the graph, before sloping downwards in a straight line for the remainder of the graph. ]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is moving at a speed of \( 2.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes the gradient of a speed-time graph is the speed"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is accelerating at a rate of \( 2.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is stationary for \( 2.5 \) hours",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "The car is decelerating at a rate of \( 2.5 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{h}^{2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes an upward slope on a speed-time graph shows negative acceleration"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1844/1869:

[
    {
        "question": {

            "Question": "\( y=(x-3)(x-5) \) \( y=(x-3)(x-5) \) Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis? Where does this curve intercept the \( y \) axis?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (0,-8) \) \( (0,-8) \)",
                "Misconception": "Adds instead of multiplying when expanding bracket"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( \begin{array}{c}(0,3) \\ \text { and } \\ (0,5)\end{array} \) \( \begin{array}{c}(0,3) \\ \text { and } \\ (0,5)\end{array} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes that the y intercept is where y = 0"
            },

                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( (0,-15) \) \( (0,-15) \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes multiplying two negatives gives a negative answer"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

Misconception 1845/1869:
Here is another example of the same question with the same format and misconceptions:

```json
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving roots",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing calculations involving square roots.

Alex says \( \sqrt{25}-\sqrt{4}=5 \)

Ben says \( \sqrt{25-4}=5 \)

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "When adding or subtracting roots, adds or subtracts the numbers under the roots"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand square root"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

This example maintains the same format and misconceptions as the original question, but with a new scenario and calculation.

Misconception 1847/1869:
Here's another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Carry out an addition problem with integers where the answer is positive",
            "Subject": "Adding and Subtracting Negative Numbers",
            "Question": "Amir and Ria are trying to write calculations based on the diagram below.

Amir writes: \( (-8)+3=-5 \)

Ria writes: \( 3-(-8)=11 \)

Who is correct? ![Number line with an arrow marked 3 going from -8 to -5]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Amir",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that addition is the inverse operation of subtraction"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ria",
                "Misconception": "Does not recognise that adding a positive number to a negative number will give a smaller negative answer"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Amir and Ria",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not understand the diagram given in the question"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

This example is also based on the same misconceptions, but with a different scenario and numbers. Amir and Ria are trying to write calculations based on a number line diagram, and the question asks who is correct. The correct answer is C, Both Amir and Ria, but the misconceptions are similar to the original question.

[
    {
        "question": {

            "Question": "This is a part of the table of values for the equation \( \boldsymbol{y}=\boldsymbol{x}^{\mathbf{3}} \) ![\begin{tabular}{|c|c|}
\hline\( x \) & \( 3 \) \\
\hline\( y \) & W \\
\hline
\end{tabular}]() What should replace the star?"

        "answers": {

            },

                "Misconception": "Multiplies by the index"
            },

                "Answer_text": "\( 27 \)",

        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

Misconception 1850/1869:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate distance where speed and time are in the appropriate units",
            "Subject": "Real Life Graphs",
            "Question": "This displacement-time graph shows \( 8 \) minutes of Alex's journey to school.

During that time he travelled at a speed of \( 3 \mathrm{~km} / \mathrm{hour} \).

What distance should replace the star? ![The graph has its vertical axis labelled Distance (km) and it has no scale written except for a star two squares up.
The horizontal axis is labelled Time (mins) and has the scale 0, 2, 4, 6, 8 in even steps.
The graph is a straight line sloping down from (0, star) to (8, 0).
]()
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 1.5 km \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes scales on graphs must match on both axes"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 6 km \)",
                "Misconception": "Makes an assumption about the squares on a scale representing either 1 or 10"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 0.75 km \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes distance = speed/time"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 24 km \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "D"
    }
]
```

        "answers": {

            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( t=\frac{d}{s/2} \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes dividing by a unit fraction is equivalent to dividing by its reciprocal"

            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( t=\frac{d}{s} \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {

Who is correct?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {

            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not realise that to maintain balance in an equation they must add or subtract the same amount from both sides"

        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }

Misconception 1861/1869:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Round integers to the nearest 10",

            "Question": "What is \( 247 \) rounded to the nearest \( 10 \) ?"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 200 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 240 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds down instead of up"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 250 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 260 \)",
                "Misconception": "Rounds to the wrong degree of accuracy (rounds too much)"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1862/1869:
Here is another example of the same question format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate compound area involving just rectangles and squares, where the dimensions are given in the same units",
            "Subject": "Compound Area",
            "Question": "Mia, Jake and Emily want to find the area of the garden. They each do it a different way. Who is correct? ![A compound shape made up of two rectangles.  Dimensions are 8 cm by 10 cm and also 5 cm by 6 cm. Two sides do not have measurements so need to be deduced]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Mia: \( 10 \times 8+6 \times 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Jake: \( 9 \times 8+5 \times 8 \)",
                "Misconception": "Cannot identify the correct side lengths to use when asked to find the area of a face"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Emily: \( 10 \times 9-8 \times 5 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not know how to find missing lengths in a composite shape"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "They are all correct",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "A"
    }
]

Note: I've kept the same format and misconceptions, and generated a new question with different dimensions and names.

Misconception 1863/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Carry out division problems involving one negative integer",
            "Subject": "Multiplying and Dividing Negative Numbers",
            "Question": "\( 15 \div(-5)= \)"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -20 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 20 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -3 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Believes dividing a positive by a negative gives a positive answer"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Let me know if you need more examples!

Misconception 1864/1869:
Here is another example:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Calculate the range from a list of data",
            "Subject": "Range and Interquartile Range from a List of Data",
            "Question": "What is the range of the following numbers?
\[
2,8,3,12,-4
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 3 \)",
                "Misconception": "Finds the mode rather than the range"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 14 \)",
                "Misconception": "To find the range adds the biggest and smallest number rather than subtract"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 10 \)",
                "Misconception": "Does not include negative numbers when calculating a range"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "C"
    }
]

Misconception 1865/1869:
Here is another example in the same format:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe an enlargement, with no centre of enlargement given, by a positive scale factor bigger than 1",
            "Subject": "Length Scale Factors in Similar Shapes",
            "Question": "Shape \( R \) is an enlargement of shape \( S \).
What calculation works out the constant of proportionality from shape \( S \) to shape \( R \) ? ![To similar triangle shapes labelled S and R. They have the same side labelled for S it is 4cm and for R it is 16cm]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \div 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating a scale factor, thinks the division is the other way around."
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16 \div 4 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 4 \times 16 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating a scale factor, multiplies instead of dividing."
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 16-4 \)",
                "Misconception": "When calculating a scale factor, thinks they need to subtract rather than divide."
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```

This example has the same misconceptions and format as the original, but with a new question and different shapes.

Misconception 1866/1869:
Here is another example with the same misconceptions:

```
[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Use the order of operations to carry out calculations involving addition, subtraction, multiplication, and/or division",
            "Subject": "BIDMAS",
            "Question": "What does the following equal?
\[
12 - 4 + 2 \times 5
\]"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 30 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 18 \)",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "\( -6 \)",
                "Misconception": "Applies BIDMAS in strict order (does not realize addition and subtraction, and multiplication and division, are of equal priority)"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "\( 26 \)",
                "Misconception": "Carries out operations from left to right regardless of priority order"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]
```
Let me know if you need anything else!

Misconception 1867/1869:
Here is another example of a question that maintains the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Distinguish between congruency and similarity",
            "Subject": "Congruency in Triangles",
            "Question": "Alex and Ben are discussing congruence and similarity. Who is correct? Alex says these two triangles are congruent ![An image of two triangles. One is smaller and rotated, but they are similar.]() Ben says these two triangles are similar ![An image of two triangles. One is smaller and rotated, but they are similar.]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Alex",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Ben",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Ben",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Thinks congruent shapes are the same shape but can be different sizes"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Misconception 1868/1869:
Here is another example of the same question with the same format and misconceptions:

[
    {
        "question": {
            "ConstructName": "Describe a 90° or 270° rotation giving the angle and direction of rotation, and the coordinates of the centre of rotation, where the centre of rotation lies on the edge or outside of the object ",
            "Subject": "Rotation",
            "Question": "Alex and Maya are arguing about how to fully describe the rotation from shape \( P \) to shape \( Q \)

Alex says: "a rotation of \( +90^{\degree} \) clockwise"

Maya says: "a rotation of \( 270^{\degree} \) about \( (3,-2)^{\prime \prime} \)

Who is correct? ![A coordinate grid with two rectangles drawn on it and a centre of rotation marked on, two spaces to the right and one space down from the origin. Rectangle P has the coordinates: (1,3) (3,3) (3,1) and (1,1). Rectangle Q has the coordinates: (2,0) (4,0) (4,-2) and (2,-2).]()"
        },
        "answers": {
            "Answer_A": {
                "Answer_text": "Only
Alex",
                "Misconception": "Forgets to give the centre of rotation"
            },
            "Answer_B": {
                "Answer_text": "Only Maya",
                "Misconception": "nan"
            },
            "Answer_C": {
                "Answer_text": "Both Alex and Maya",
                "Misconception": "Forgets to give the centre of rotation"
            },
            "Answer_D": {
                "Answer_text": "Neither is correct",
                "Misconception": "Does not know about the + notation for directions in rotations"
            }
        },
        "Correct_Answer": "B"
    }
]

Note that I've kept the same misconception for each answer, and only changed the names, shapes, and coordinates in the question. Let me know if you'd like me to generate another example!
